awd_titl_txt: Conference: Advancing Team Effectiveness in a Globalized World; Michigan State University, October 8-10, 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description of Significance and Importance 

A variety of global forces unfolding over the last two decades have pushed organizations world-wide to restructure work around teams to harness diverse expertise for innovation and to enable more rapid, flexible, and adaptive responses. The dual needs of innovation and adaptability make teams the focus for skill development, knowledge sharing, and action. Moreover, the push toward collaboration and teamwork is global, as critical expertise is sought wherever it is located. Aided by technology, virtual teaming is ubiquitous. This has increased the diversity of team members and the heterogeneity of their cultural and ethnic backgrounds. This places primary emphasis on melding diversity and minimizing the potential for fragmentation, subgroup formation, and faultlines that fracture teams. Modern work teams are increasingly global, multicultural, and virtual. Given the increasing prominence of multicultural teams, one would expect that there would be a strong scientific foundation and conferences devoted to this topic, but that is not the case. There are literatures on culture and diversity, but they are not team centric. There are well-developed literatures on composing, training and developing, leading, and managing teams, but a focus on multicultural issues and their implications for team effectiveness theory and research is diffuse. This represents a significant gap in the literature. The purpose of the conference is to surface key conceptual gaps, synthesize differing perspectives, and advance an agenda for theory development and research to enhance multicultural team effectiveness. Multicultural team effectiveness encompasses important substantive topics of culture, diversity, and team effectiveness. Integrating these topics advances broader scientific and societal concerns as well. Recent research shows that science and engineering are increasingly collaborative and cross-disciplinary, and that collaborative science has more impact. Collaborative science entails multicultural teams. Advancing knowledge of how to ensure the success of multicultural teams will also advance diversity in science and technology.

Technical Description 

There is a clear need to develop a more integrated understanding of the effects of culture and diversity across the spectrum of topics relevant to forming, developing, and leading effective teams. The fragmented literature necessitates theoretical integration, new research to close knowledge gaps, and the development of innovative applications to aid teamwork in multicultural contexts. The conference is designed to advance this integration by (a) targeting key experts across core topic areas (i.e., culture, diversity, team training, team leadership, and team effectiveness); (b) having them share their knowledge and insights on new developments across core topics; and (c) engaging them and diverse conference participants in interactive, focused discussion sessions to integrate ideas, identify gaps, and propose promising directions for synthesis, theory development, and new research. This approach will help to integrate this fragmented literature and to organize a coherent framework for conceptual progress, research advancement, and practical applications to improve multicultural team effectiveness. In addition, products from the conference will be publically available. Presentation materials and consented videos of presentations will be available for downloading from the Consortium for Multicultural Psychology Research (CMPR) website at the Department of Psychology, Michigan State University.

por.por_cntn:
Work in the contemporary world is largely accomplished by individuals working collaboratively in teams. Teamwork allows for harnessing and combining different perspectives and skillsets, resulting in faster and more efficient problem-solving. Given the ever-increasing rate of globalization, coupled with technological advances that have enabled individuals located in different countries to interface with each other, more and more work teams are composed of members that cut across different cultures. However, an important concern is that in some cases teamwork within multicultural groups may be impeded due to differences among members. For example, teammates who are demographically similar to one another may form subgroups distinct from other teammates who do not share their similarities?not surprisingly, this hampers successful collaboration for the team as a collective. Another concern is that scientific understanding of the unique patterns of functioning for multicultural teams is quite limited. Although there are substantial bodies of research in the areas of culture, diversity, team training, team leadership, and team effectiveness, very little research has been conducted to synthesize findings across these related areas with a specific focus on multicultural team effectiveness.

The 2015 Michigan State University Symposium on Multicultural Teams was held to develop scientific understanding on important areas requiring greater study from a variety of experts in distinct yet relevant research domains. The symposium was held on October 9-10, 2015 at the Marriott Hotel in East Lansing, Michigan. Twelve prominent national and international researchers provided their expert perspectives on the theme of multicultural team effectiveness. The presenters were: Dr. Paula Caligiuri (Northeastern University), Dr. Noshir Contractor (Northwestern University), Dr. Leslie DeChurch (Georgia Institute of Technology), Dr. Michelle Gelfand (University of Maryland), Dr. David Harrison (University of Texas, Austin), Dr. Dora Lau (Chinese University of Hong Kong), Dr. Rodger T. A. J. Leenders (Tilberg University), Dr. Susan Mohammed (Pennsylvania State University), Dr. John Mathieu (University of Connecticut), Dr. Daniel A. Newman (University of Illinois), Dr. Scott Page (University of Michigan), and Dr. Quinetta Roberson (Villanova University). Three discussants each facilitated an interactive dialog between the speakers and attendees. The discussants were: Dr. Jonathon Cummings (Duke University), Dr. Eduardo Salas (Rice University), and Dr. John M. Schaubroeck (Michigan State University). Over 60 people, mainly university professors and graduate students from across the region, attended the 1.5-day symposium.

The symposium generated several valuable contributions. Downloadable pdf versions of the presentations made by speakers are freely available to the public via the website hosted by the Consortium for Multicultural Psychology Research at Michigan State University. Furthermore, several graduate students who attended the symposium went on to develop their own research projects on topics related to cultural diversity and team effectiveness. Presenters' reflections on the needed research to advance understanding of multicultural teams formed the basis for a research agenda that was generated by the symposium. This agenda will be useful for the wider scientific community to direct research efforts towards the most critical areas for research. In sum, the 2015 Michigan State University Symposium on Multicultural Teams was a marked success and resulted in several beneficial contributions towards enhancing the effectiveness of multicultural teams in a globalized world.
